direction.raw_text: Let me get this straight. The girl with the big lips is depressed because, each night, when her father goes off to work at the bakery, her mother sneaks some mysterious lover into the house. Not only does this girl have to listen to her mother working this guy in the next room, she has to wash the sheets each morning before Daddy gets home. After a few weeks of this, she starts to go a little nutty/ so Daddy takes her to confession--only, once she gets in the box, she gets a whiff of the priest and realizes he's the mother's secret lover. Is that it? James Leer says nothing, huddling lower in the PATTY OVERCOAT he wears.

Q (cont'd) As a writer, one thing you learn is that everyone you encounter has a story. Every bartender, every taxi driver, everybody has an idea or a. story that would make a "great book" or a "great movie." Presumably, each of you has an idea. (gestures to the audience) But, how do you go from there to here? How do you go from having an idea to having a book? How do you get across? What is the bridge, the bridge that allows you to walk on air from the shoreline of inspiration to the terra firma of accomplishment? Faith. Faith that your story is worth the telling, faith that you have the wherewithal to tell it, faith that the carefully woven structure you create won't collapse beneath you...

direction.raw_text: Apparently not even Hannah Green has a clue as to the location of your apartment.

direction.raw_text: tosses the tin of band-aids into a small plastic hand basket, begins to move down the aisle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got kicked out. Well, not exactly kicked out. I was asked to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess there's probably a story behind that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is, but it's not that interesting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So where have you been staying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bus station.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stares incredulously at James.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not -so bad. I know the night janitor. And there's a broken locker I can put my stuff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But James. I mean. ..How long?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A couple weeks. That's why... that's why I had the gun. For protection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus, James, you should've told someone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know... (unconvincingly) Me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: drops the basket at the check-out counter and, abruptly, finds himself face to face with a BABY, lolling on the shoulder of the woman before him. The baby is staring, spellbound, at a display of...Q'S LATEST PAPERBACK. GRADY frowns, then detects the true source of enchantment: a spray of SHINY MYLAR GIFT BALLOONS. A thought evolves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you think of these? James takes another chug from his jug, nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice. 51
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grady, squinting through the ten-inch panel of cleared ice on the windshield, roils slowly up onto the curb in front of Walter and Sara Gaskell's house ...then off. 52
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pops the glovebox, takes out a PEN, and scratches something on the GIFT CARD attached to the BALLOON. James glances briefly at a plump ZIPLOC OF POT stashed in the glovebox, then peers at the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't this...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: gets out, then pauses, glancing at the giant orange juice jug between James legs. It's about half-down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You better ease off that stuff, James. It's pretty acidic. James takes a powdered donut that lies on his coat, studies it curiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't help myself. I don't know what's the matter with me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shit, James, you're hungover. What do you think's the matter with you? As GRADY turns away, James ponders this, then considers the ring of white sugar imprinted on his coat and re-sets the donut in precisely the same place. 53
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Through the steamy panes, we SEE GRADY approach with the balloon, enter. He crosses to a high table, sets the balloon down, and steps back, considering the placement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Feeling guilty?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: jumps--startled--and turns. Sara has materialized behind a ficus, large POTTING GLOVES on her hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't believe you hung up on me, you dick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Totally.  I'm sorry. A lot was happening this morning. Can you talk? Sara nods, moves the ficus to another table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walter's on campus, being the good soldier for WordFest. But he's a basket case. Someone stole Marilyn's jacket last night. And Poe's missing, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I-heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard? How?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A twelve-year-old policeman came by the house this morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you confess?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks up, mildly alarmed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your fingerprints were all over the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really? That was fast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm kidding. Hello?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. Right. Ha. Listen, about last night. There is something I need to tell...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you limping? Why are you limping?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hub? Oh, well, that's part of what I need to . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you pass out again, Grady? Did you fall somewhere?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I mean. Well, actually, yes. Sort of. I don't remember. Listen, Sara, I have to tell you something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right. Sara settles back, folds her arms. Waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... As GRADY stares into Sara's eyes, things begin to blur. GRADY (cont'd) ...want to be with you. Sara looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gee, Grady, that sounded so heartfelt.  I don't know whether to swoon or smirk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really, Sara, I... Sara holds up one gloved hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe you. I believe you want to be with me. But this is not just about me anymore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know that. I know what's at stake here...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I don't think you do. And besides... I haven't decided yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About the baby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That ...and you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: goes still, watches Sara strip off the gloves, drop them on  a table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not going to draw the map for you on this one, Grady. Times like these you have to do your own navigating. Sara turns to leave, then stops, squinting far down the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's that sitting in your car?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: James Leer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's he doing out there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sort of helping him work through some issues. Sara raises an eyebrow, then pushes through the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't he lucky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: watches her ripple across the glass, head for the house, and wave. James, slumped low in the Galaxie, offers a limp hand in return, but it's too late. She's already gone. 54
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: cradles the wheel in his bandaged paw, while James sits stiffly, the orange juice jug bobbing between his thighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She seemed to take it pretty well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, well, actually. . . James looks over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The moment didn't really present itself. James nods, unsurprised, then turns back to the window, staring at the landscape, still sitting oddly still. GRADY glances at him. At the orange juice jug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You' re not planning on puking in my car, are you, James? Nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be proud, James. We're in Sewickley Heights. We could find you a nice golf course to barf on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks over, surprised by the James' tone. James blinks, looks embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean. I'm fine. I'm sorry. I just... James peers out the window at passing landscape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got a thing about, ..places like this. I know what those houses are like. I know what the people are like.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your aunt ? James turns, eyes flashing with surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hannah mentioned something about an aunt. James nods vaguely, then reaches into the ashtray, takes a JOINT between his fingers, sniffs it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Humboldt County?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's my father. He gets it from his doctor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Glaucoma?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Colon cancer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus, James. Wow. James puts the joint back in the ashtray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a bit of a scandal. My parents live in a small town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carvel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carvel? Where's Carvel?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Outside Scranton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never heard of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a hellhole. Three motels and a mannequin factory. My dad worked there for thirty-five years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your father worked in a mannequin factory?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seitz Plastics. That's where he met my morn. She was a fry cook in the cafeteria. Before that, she'd been a dancer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of dancer? .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever kind they wanted her to be.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: James Leer, are you telling me your mother was a stripper?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm telling you what I was told by my uncle. And he should know. He ran half a dozen men's clubs in Baltimore before he skipped town on a bad debt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't you say your Mom went to Catholic school?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When we fall, we fall hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amazing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: takes the joint from the ashtray, lights it, then notices-with surprise--James has his hand out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you were the guy who didn't like to lose control of his emotions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe I just needed the moment to present itself. 55
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .(ONE HOUR LATER)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: glides down the graceful, tree-lined streets of a modest, but well-kept neighborhood. James still has the JOINT-now only a tiny nub-pinched between his fingers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is so nice. It's like where Andy Hardy would live. What's it called again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kinship.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kinship. And what's here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unless I miss my bet...my wife. James' heavy eyelids flutter with surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The one that left you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right. That one. 56
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the front door, then cups his hands against the glass of the living room window, squints inside. Nothing. As he turns away, GRADY sees James sitting on the hood of the Galaxie with the box of powdered donuts. He's sitting in the indentation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Someone jumped on your car with their butt ..-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can you tell?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can see the outline of a butt. As GRADY nods, James holds out the donut box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Want one. They're incredible. Incredible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smoke the rest of that joint, James, and you can start on the box. 58
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As GRADY steps onto the back porch, James follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe she didn't come here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She came here. We'll just wait. In the meantime, I need you to shimmy through. James stares at the "Doggy Door" cut into the back porch door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Relax. Emily hasn't carried a house key since she was twelve years old. And your hips are as slim as hers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not that. It just reminded me of-- you know-of what's in the car. In the trunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. Right. Well, let's try not to think about that. James takes another sad glance at the little door, then drops onto ail fours. 59
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: leads James through the house. Everything about it speaks of family. Even the furniture seems arranged so that people will gather together, light a fire, talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It feels really... good. ..here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. It's the house you want to wake up in on Christmas morning. (moving off) Make yourself at home. I'll be right back. 60
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grady, laboring badly on his ankle", enters and finds a DUFFEL BAG open on the floor, its contents a tangle of quickly-packed clothes. Everything else in the room feels of another time. PHOTOGRAPHS are everywhere, documenting a PRETTY GIRL'S life, from first recital to cap and gown. One photograph lies face down. GRADY turns it over and finds the pretty girl grown into a beautiful young woman, standing in a white gown next to a younger Grady--on their wedding day. 61
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: James enters, FRENCH ROLL in hand, and sees a REMOTE CONTROL atop the BAR. Taking it, he points it at the WIDE- SCREEN TELEVISION imbedded in the opposite wall and, seconds later, GEORGE SANDERS walks into his CLOSE-UP.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no such thing as a good influence, Mr. Gray. All influence is immoral... 62
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grady, a PINK PRINCESS PHONE to his ear, lies on the bed next to a huge TEDDY BEAR.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I' m looking for the Chancellor... I don't know. She should be in the main hall ...Thank you. 63
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: James runs through the channels, pauses on MARTIN MILNER and GEORGE MAHARIS, riding in their curvy Corvette. 64
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nelson Riddle's THEME FROM ROUTE 66 BOOMS from below, GRADY cups a hand over his ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sara? Hi. It's Grady.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you, Grady? An elevator?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm in Kinship. Listen, Sara, there's some things we need to talk about...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're in Kinship?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. But that's not why I called...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With Emily?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? No'. There's no one here. I'm just ...just....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just what? Doing a little dusting? As GRADY endeavors to respond, TWO YOUTHFUL VOICES, CHEERFULLY SINGING, rise from below.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good Morning! Good Morning!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: James! For Christ sake, will you turn that thing down!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: James? He's still with you? 65
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: James, in the midst of pouring himself a tumbler of Bushmills, smiles as JUDY GARLAND and MICKEY ROONEY sing their hearts out in Babes In Arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We talked the whole night through! 66
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: shakes his head, carries the phone toward the bedroom WINDOW.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, Sara. ..I'm not here. ..I'm not here to . . . As GRADY watches, a late-model PONTIAC BONNEVIlLE turns into the driveway below him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...reconcile with Emily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you there to not reconcile with her? The Bonneville's trunk pops open, revealing THREE BAGS OF GROCERIES, and HANK and IRENE WINTERS, both in their 60's, get out. An enormous NEWFOUNDLAND vaults from the backseat. Sara, eating phone static this whole time, interprets Grady's silence her own way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodbye, Grady.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Sara, you don't understand...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Trust me, I understand. I just want to say something to you, Grady.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yea?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How you choose to live your own life is your business. But you be careful with that boy, Grady. With James. He belongs to somebody else. As the line goes dead, GRADY watches Hank and Irene Winters disappear below him. 69
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: James--Irish whiskey in one hand, the pride of Humboldt County in the other--watches with deep absorption as Judy and Mickey have a heartfelt conversation. Then, sensing something ...he turns. Hank and Irene Winters, grocery bags in arm, stand frozen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: are HEARD on the staircase and GRADY hobbies into view. He tries a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom. Dad. 70
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (A BIT LATER) Hank Winters emerges from the bathroom with a roll of tape, a bottle of alcohol, and some cotton wool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it's infected, I can tell you that. I'm just going to clean it up a bit. It's up to you to-find someone who knows what they're doing. Here. Put your foot up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: puts his foot up on Hank's lazy-Boy, then notices a BOOK lying face down on the seat. The AUTHOR on the back cover looks as if he's trying very hard to look consequential. To his surprise, GRADY realizes the author is himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So he's one of your students, this boy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: glances into the living room, where James and Irene sit on a long couch together, sipping something hot. James is looking out the window, a curious expression on his face. GRADY looks out his own window, sees the Newfoundland sniffing curiously at-the Galaxie's trunk. When he glances back into the living room, he and James make brief eye contact, then blink, look away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. He's a good kid. Maybe a little messed up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm sure with the proper guidance he'll be fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: tries to read Hank's face---is he messing with him?--but Hank gives nothing away. GRADY nods to the book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What made you pull out that old thing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was thinking of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's no Arsonist's Daughter, but I guess you know that. It's a young man's book. It got me remembering how it felt to be young.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe I should read it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I don't think there's any danger of you aging prematurely, Grady.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: doesn't have to read Hank's face this time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's Emily, Hank?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'don't know if she'd want me  to tell you that, Grady.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not going to stalk her. Hank. I just. ..want to know where I stand. Hank looks up, incredulous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where you stand?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: l-just want to say I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's in Philadelphia seeing Linda Aahby. The neurologist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Neurologist? Why? What's wrong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing's wrong. They went to Wellesley together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. Right. Linda ...I haven't been doing a lot of sleeping lately. My editor's in town and I have the book to finish and--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, right. The book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: starts to continue, then stops, cowed by something in Hank's tone, something dismissive. Instead, he looks away, toward the living room, and catches sight of James again, sitting alone now with his big cup of cocoa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen, Hank, I'm sorry about ail this. I didn't come here to upset you and Irene. I want you to know that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did you come here, Grady?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: gestures vaguely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -just wanted to see her, I guess-- Emily. And to see you too-you and Irene. And to let everyone know that, even though it may be difficult to comprehend now, this-everything that's happening-it's not forever. It doesn't mean "Goodbye."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me a break, Grady. Hank snaps off the tape, slaps Grady's ankle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're done. 71
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: glowers darkly at the road, then puts his hand up against the HEATING VENT which, apparently, is not putting out any heat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm having a really good time, Professor Tripp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: glances over, sees James burrowing into the Ziploc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm really happy for you, James. But do me a favor, will you? Lay off my dope. That stuff's not for amateurs. James looks at Ziploc as GRADY fiddles with the heat LEVER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just wanted a little sip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just wanted a little sip? Tell me, James, exactly what point was it that you turned into Serpent Boy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Probably about the time you gave me the codeine pills last night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stops with the heater, glances over at James, whose face bears not the slightest trace of irony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus... (thinking, then. . . ) Look, James, you appear to possess-like many an aspiring writer before you, by the way-a rather ardent affinity for the stuff of which dreams are made. However, I 'think it's best if, for the moment at least (taking the Ziploc) ...we abstain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're mad at me, aren't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're mad because I shot your girlfriend's dog.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It wasn't her dog. It's her husband's-- (stopping) Who said anything about girlfriend? James eyes shift slowly, as if to 'say: Who are you kidding?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, James, I wish you hadn't shot my girlfriend's dog. Even though Poe and I weren't exactly what you'd call simpatico, that's no reason for him to take two in the chest. Still, the fact remains that I'm the one who took you up into the Chancellor's bedroom. I'm the one who has to take the blame. I- don't know what the hell I was thinking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure you do. You were thinking: 'That's no cap gun in that kid's overcoat.' You were thinking 'I can't let that kid get on. the bus alone-he might never get on the bus again.' You were thinking: 'I've got to find a way to distract this kid. ' So you did. It was--in its way--a noble act.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks for the halo, James, but I've . never done that much thinking ahead in my" life-ever. James looks -out the window, pondering this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, why did you take me up there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I -don' t know, James . I don' t know why I do half the things I do. Who does? (looking over) Why do you wear that coat? James looks down, a little defensive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's warm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: James, fall semester, first day of class, it was 95 degrees and you were wearing the coat. James just blinks, no ready answer-available.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's why they all give you such a hard time in workshop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because of my coat?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because you act like a goddamn spook all the time. Not to mention the fact that every last one of them is jealous of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jealous? Of me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not you. Your talent. James' face hardens. He looks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're lying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The hell I am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes you are. My stuff stinks. I know it. You said so yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never said that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes you did. Last night. To your friend Crabtree. "Is he any good?" he said. And you said: "Not yet he isn't." I heard you myself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't mean it that way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's okay, Professor Tripp. Carrie, Howard, the others--they 're right. My stories are annoying. They go on and on and on, and the longer they go on the more annoying they become, until finally you just want to grab something heavy and--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shut up, James. You're annoying. Carrie and Howard don't know what the fuck they're talking about, okay? The entire class combined- including the lovely Hannah Green-has about one tenth of one percent the talent you have, okay? James stares blankly at Grady, then turns his face to the window. He ponders Grady's words, the praise inherent in them. A hint of pleasure glints in his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But, last night...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who cares what-. I said last night, James I I was drunk, I was stoned. I'd been bitten by a dog. My wife had left me. How 'bout cutting me some slack?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And don't be so goddamn sensitive. Who cares what anybody thinks anyway? You want to .be a good writer? You want to be-a great writer? Then stop giving a damn what other people think. Most of them haven't thought in .years. James turns, studies Grady's face as it flickers in the first headlights of the evening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me spell it .out for you, James. Books don't mean anything. Not to anybody. Not anymore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arsonist's Daughter meant something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: smiles contemptuously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean it. It means something to me. It's one of the reasons I came to school here. To be in your class. To be taught by you. (quietly) It's one of the reasons I wanted to become a writer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stares ahead, watching the darkness tumble away before the wide sweep of the Galaxie's headlights.

direction.raw_text: Well, for that, if nothing else, James, I'm sorry. 72

direction.raw_text: You coming?

direction.raw_text: In a minute. Get us a table. James nods, pushes past the glass doors into the coffee shop, and a big REDHEAD in a waitress cap leads him to a table with a view of the highway. GRADY watches James-- stick figure in black brogues--slide into the booth and open his big, laminated menu. Finally, as if concluding some internal debate, GRADY kicks open his door, steps out. 73INT/
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: rests his forehead against the PAYPHONE as he speaks.

direction.raw_text: C-a-r-v-e-I. That's right, Carvel. Yes, I'm sure. It's outside Scranton.

direction.raw_text: straightens up, takes a peek at James, sitting by himself on the far side of the coffee shop.

direction.raw_text: You have no listing. Okay, well, lady-- at this very moment, as we speak, I'm looking of a resident of Carvel, Pennsylvania. I think he'd be pretty interested to learn that the good people of Bell Atlantic have misplaced his entire hometown. It's not like I'm making this up as I go along--

direction.raw_text: stops, his own words ringing in his head.

direction.raw_text: Never mind. My mistake. 74

direction.raw_text: upends James' knapsack, sifts through: An AUTOGRAPHED POSTCARD of FRANCES FARMER. A wrinkled box of CHICLETS. Nothing. Then he notices ERROL FLYNN'S eyebrows peeking at him from the knapsack's side pouch. He takes the book, opens it. Bingo. A library notice: James Seiwyn Leer is three weeks overdue. Under ADDRESS it says only: "On File." But if one was to dial the PHONE NUMBER, odds are it won't be the night janitor at the Greyhound depot who picks up. 75

result.heading: GIANT PIECE OF LEMON MERINGUE PIE

direction.raw_text: The remains of a FRIED CLAM SANDWICH sit before James as he turns his attention to a GIANT PIECE OF LEMON MERINGUE PIE. GRADY sips only coffee, stealing glances at the cars that whip by on the highway beyond the window.

direction.raw_text: Want a bite?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's why you're having them. Your spells.

direction.raw_text: Spells? Jesus, James, you make it sound like we're in a Tennessee Williams play. I don't have spells.

direction.raw_text: When?

direction.raw_text: I just worry about you, that's all. ...then pass. James' words finally register. GRADY looks at him.

direction.raw_text: You just worry about yourself, James. Okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. Just then, a long, pale WAND of LIGHT splinters against the coffee shop windows and a CAR sweeps into the parking lot. GRADY follows it with his eyes, rises.

direction.raw_text: Where you going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: moves off, then stops, looking back at James and his giant piece of pie, still troubled by his words. 76

direction.raw_text: As GRADY limps out of the coffee shop, he finds an OLDER MAN in a TUXEDO standing in the open door of a gleaming BLACK MERCEDES. Beyond him, in the front passenger seat, a WOMAN in MINK examines her eye shadow in the tiny mirror of the sun visor.

direction.raw_text: Professor Tripp?

direction.raw_text: Grady.

direction.raw_text: considers the two glittering ghosts before him. They seem to be waiting. Just waiting.

direction.raw_text: Well. Let me go get him.

direction.raw_text: I "hope you won't consider this forward of me, Amanda, but I wonder if I might ask. ..did you ever attend Catholic school? Amanda Leer's eyes narrow ever-so-slightly.

direction.raw_text: I'm not going with them..

direction.raw_text: James. Listen. Things-things are a little weird with me right now and I-- well--I have enough blame to shoulder these days without having to take the blame if something bad happened to you. And if you hang around me long enough, something bad is going to happen, trust me. That's why I need you to go home. Understand?

direction.raw_text: I'm not going, with them.

direction.raw_text: stares at-James wearily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I swear. My father had his own airplane he used to fly up to Quebec. One Christmas, he and my mom were flying up to our house in the Laurentians when the plane went down. It was in the newspaper.

direction.raw_text: doesn't flinch, unpersuaded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'swear. My father was a senior vice president at Dravo. My mother was a socialite. Her maiden name was Guggenheim.

direction.raw_text: starts to protest, then pauses.

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry about all that. I just-I don't like to talk about my family. They treat me like a freak. (nodding towards Amanda) She makes me sleep in. the basement of my own house. It's mine. My parents left it to me.

direction.raw_text: glances toward the parking lot, studies the contours of Fred Leer's face. Frowns.

direction.raw_text: James, come on. That man is obviously your father. You look just like him. James looks down at the table, takes a deep breath, and speaks in a voice heavy with implication.

direction.raw_text: There's a reason for that. Grady's addled brain grapples with this dark little riddle, finally deciphers what James is suggesting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get out of here.

direction.raw_text: That's why she hates me. That's why she makes me sleep in the basement.

direction.raw_text: I swear. 78

direction.raw_text: Oh, don't worry. We'll take care of him. You can be sure of that. GRADY glances down at his spattered self, then notices, sitting on the front passenger seat, James' knapsack. GRADY grabs it, turns.

direction.raw_text: Hey!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as the Mercedes begins to pull away and James turns, elbows on the back dash, his pale face slack. Spying Grady, he raises one limp hand, and then-as if it were held by a string-lets it drop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey. 79

direction.raw_text: Nobody teaches a writer anything. You tell them what you know. You tell them to find their voice and stick with it, because that's all you have in the end. You tell the ones who have it to keep at it and you tell the ones who don't to keep at it, too. Because that's the only way to get where you're going. (ruefully) Of course, it helps if you know where you want to go. (thoughtfully) Maybe that's the only thing--that and Sara-- that's made the last seven years worthwhile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: slides James' knapsack off his shoulder, smiles cryptically as he considers it. -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As for James, he doesn't need me anymore... Without warning, GRADY tosses CRABTREE the knapsack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's got you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stares at the saggy green canvas in his hands, watches GRADY walk away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me? What can I do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gee, I don't know, Crabs... (over his shoulder) Improvise. You're good at that.

direction.raw_text: continues on, leaving CRABTREE to stand alone, as he walks toward the buildings in the distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, Tripp.

direction.raw_text: stops, turns.

direction.raw_text: I peeked. GRADY considers this. Nods. It-doesn't seem to matter anymore

direction.raw_text: It really had the makings, Tripp. There was a lot to admire. I've ...never read anything quite like it. If there was a Kentucky Derby for editorial bullshit, Crabtree's last three utterances would finish win, place, and show. And GRADY knows it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not just trying to make me feel better?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks directly at Grady, his old friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scout's honor.

direction.raw_text: and GRADY stare into each other's eyes. Both are acutely aware of the subtext of this conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, thanks for that, Crabs. 111
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dead quiet. Gradually, STEPS are heard, coming from the stairwell, then GRADY limps into view. 112
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: surveys the room. Empty chairs. Empty desks. He walks to a WINDOW, the same window he stood at two afternoons ago when reading James Leer's story. A chill breeze pitches the fabric of his shirt as he studies the barren benches and icy walkways of the quad. Finally, he-. turns away, settles behind his desk and, reaching into his pocket, removes the seven remaining pages of his manuscript. He considers them, then folds them in half length-wise. He continues, folding the top right corner down into a triangle along the first crease... 113

direction.raw_text: A moment. Then-from the third floor window-a PAPER AIRPLANE glides into view, soaring then dropping, soaring then dropping, again and again, graceful as a dove. 114

direction.raw_text: hobbles into the lobby just as one of the auditorium doors swings open. APPLAUSE SWELLS and he spies Sara standing inside, talking to a STUDENT USHER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sara! Sara turns ...as the door glides shut. As GRADY hustles forward, Q, wine glass in hand, intercepts him. Q Grady. I have to tell you. I took another look at Arsonist's Daughter the other night. There's a description of a bald cypress that left' me breathless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, Q. I felt the same way about the bank teller's breasts in your last one. 115
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: enters, but Sara is ...gone. He picks his way behind the back row, scanning the aisles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Professor Tripp. It's Carrie McWhirty, James' tormentor from workshop. GRADY takes another look around, then drops into the seat- next to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you're looking for Hannah, she's on the aisle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No... But GRADY looks anyway. Hannah sits a dozen rows down the aisle, hair pulled back in a clip, glorious skin gloaming. The Goatee Kid sits close beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's that guy she's with? Didn't he used to be in workshop?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff. He comes from a long line of tango dancers. 116

direction.raw_text: Walter turns over the last page of-his prepared notes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now, as those of you who've been with us in previous years know, we have a tradition of sorts here at WordFest. I'm speaking, of course, of The Plums. An anticipatory BUZZ sweeps through the audience as Walter begins to read from a separate list.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This weekend, Susan Lowery, of North Braddock, found a publisher for her children's book. The Loneliest Prawn, Susan, stand up. 117
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ^ As a CHUBBY WOMAN stands to acknowledge the applause, GRADY cranes his neck, searching the sea of seats. To his surprise, he finds CRABTREE sitting prominently in the front row, in his shirtsleeves, smiling his spookily complacent smile. James is next to him, now wearing CRABTREE'S METALLIC SPORTS COAT over Grady's flannel shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Robert Wilkenson--who many of you know for his City Beat column in the Post-Gazette--has found a home with Putnam for his new Three Rivers thriller. Blood Patterns. Robert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stands briefly then Walter's VOICE takes a shift in tone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, this next one, I think, is especially exciting to announce, because it concerns a student here at the university. Our own James Leer, a sophomore in English literature, has found a publisher for his first novel, which I believe is called The Lovely Parade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: blinks, leans forward, and watches Walter smile warmly toward the front row. CRABTREE gives James a jab in the ribs and slowly, awkwardly, James rises. Stunned, Carrie McWhirty turns to the GIRL next to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have a class with him. James hangs-like a scarecrow from a nail, waiting as the APPLAUSE slows, then sputters, then dies out altogether.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The guy's kind of an alien probe, if you know what I mean. Grady, in a last attempt to save James from himself, cups Hi his hands around his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take a bow, James! James turns, spots GRADY in the back row, then-a sheepish grin on his face--spreads his arms, hangs his head, and takes his first sweet public bow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wonder Boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And finally--and perhaps not least importantly--Terry Crabtree, of Bartizan, has also decided to publish my own book--a critical exploration of the union of Marilyn Monroe and Joe DiMaggio and its function in American mythopoetics-which, tentatively, I've entitled The Last American Marriage.     " Wild, obsequious APPLAUSE. GRADY smiles cynically, watches Walter take a brief, dignified bow of his own. . :
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Until next year. Thank you, everyone. The LIGHTS come up. As the auditorium empties, CRABTREE shakes Walter's hand and Jeff and his goatee escort Hannah Green down the aisle, where she drapes her lovely arms around James.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: watches them ail, sitting alone in his row, when suddenly Sara appears over James' shoulder. She says something congratulatory, turns, and exits out a side door. GRADY blinks, scrambles up. 118
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: bursts into the corridor.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sara! Its empty. Quiet. GRADY pauses. Somewhere, a HEAVY METAL DOOR CLOSES. GRADY rushes on. 119
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grady, limping badly, turns a corner and sees a DOOR. He moves to it, pushes past... 120
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and finds himself standing in a stairwell. He leans out over the railing, peers down. It's a steep drop, very. steep, ending in a small rectangular space, a kind of basement office, with VENDING MACHINES, PLASTIC CHAIRS, and a COLLAPSIBLE CARD TABLE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: turns back to the door he came through, pushes against it. Locked. He sighs, looks back at the stairs, his ailing ankle, then sits. He fishes out the Ziploc of- marijuana, considers the perfectly roiled JOINT floating atop the bag of buds, but, for once, isn't up to it. The SOUND of FOOTSTEPS echoes far below and, hopeful they're Sara's, GRADY pulls himself up, peers over the railing. It's Traxler, with a broom, a big plastic bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yo, Traxler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Professor Tripp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: considers the Ziploc in his hand, looks down again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you get high, Sam?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only when I'm working.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hangs-over the railing and lets fly the Ziploc.  It pinwheels through the vortex of stairs, lands at Sam's feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holy shit. Are you serious?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As a heart attack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks-Whoa, Professor Tripp, careful ^here...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is still hanging over the railing-but looking dizzy now. His eyelids flutter and he tips forward-a Steinway on a window ledge-and as he starts to drop... ...there is a SHARP JERK on his- COLLAR, a SHIRT BUTTON caroms off his cheek, and slowly, he is hauled back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grady, what are you doing, you idiot?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks up into Sara's freckled face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looking for you. He wants to say more, he opens his mouth, but then... ALL GOES BLACK AS SARA'S VOICE CALLS... faintly at first, then more forcefully, calling Grady's name, calling so insistently that the earth seems to RUSH upward until we see that she is...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: him or something, and all goes softly... Blue. 121

direction.raw_text: lies in a powder blue paper gown surrounded by blue plastic curtains in a blue room. Through a gap in the curtains, he can see the bottle of-GLUCOSE that drips slowly into his arm, and beyond, a window. Flakes of SNOW fall outside. The DOOR SQUEALS, a SHADOW ripples across the blue, then the curtains part and a RESIDENT with a clipboard appears. His NAMETAG says GREENHUT.

direction.raw_text: I passed out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been doing that a lot lately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So I hear. You've also been smoking a lot of marijuana, I understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think that's why I've been having these... (grabbing James' term) ... spells?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long have you been having them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The last month maybe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long have you been smoking marijuana?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spiro T. Agnew was vice president, I believe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's probably not the problem, then. What about your lifestyle. Any major changes recently?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been trying to finish a book...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And your wife left you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that in my chart?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I spoke with the woman who saved your life. You're lucky she came along when she did.

direction.raw_text: considers the larger ramifications of this statement
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You need to see a doctor, Mr. Tripp. An internist. And I think you really ought to consider seeing a therapist, as well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She told you about. . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her dog, yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Actually, it was her husband's dog... Greenhut glances up, looking GRADY in the eyes for the first time, and GRADY stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, Mr. Tripp. You have a drug problem, all right? On top of that, you have a bite on your ankle that is severely infected. We pumped you with antibiotics so you'll be fine, but another day or two and you might have lost the foot. As for your spells. I'm guessing they're a result of the anxiety you've been experiencing lately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're anxiety attacks? That's a little disappointing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Better luck next time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So is my friend...is Sara still here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. There's no one here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to see her. As soon as possible. Greenhut studies Grady, calibrating the desperation in his eyes, then takes a quick glance at his watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, Mr. Tripp. If you really want to leave, I can't stop you. But I'm going to write you a prescription for a course of ampicillin and I want you to follow it to the end-no matter how stupid you decide to be with everything else. All right? 122
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sits in a WHEELCHAIR, watching the snow fail around him as a NURSE escorts him through the tunnel of glass that connects one building to another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wonder if you could show me something. 123        EXT. NURSERY - HOSPITAL - MOMENTS LATER GRADY stares through the glass. There are only TWO BABIES on display, heads dented from natural delivery, skin purple and crazy with veins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are these the only ones you have? The nurse's eyes crinkle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kidding... 124        EXT. GASKELL HOUSE - LATE AFTERNOON GRADY pays a TAXI CAB DRIVER, then turns,     looks at the Gaskell house. 125
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Nothing. Peers into the living room window. Dark.  He stands helplessly, then spies the greenhouse, standing ghostly across the yard, feathers of snow drifting onto its roof, melting. 126
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hobbles to the greenhouse, puts both hands to the glass as he looks inside. Quiet. Empty. Dispirited, he pulls away, but not before leaving... ...the IMPRINTS of his hands, perfectly etched in the frost of the glass. 127
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The snow continues to fall as GRADY lumbers down the street. Finally, wearily, he stops, sits his crippled self on the curb. He plunges his fist into his jacket and. ..straight through the lining, James Leer's silly little pistol at the end of his hand. He considers the pistol, then looks up into the sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - of the SKY... ...dark and menacing. Suddenly, a THUNDERCLAP shatters the silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...still sitting with the gun in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that a suggestion?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sits, blinking the snow out of his eyes, then TWO SHAFTS of-LIGHT dance across his shoes. A white Citroen DS23 appears.  It passes.  Slows.  Stops. GRADY stares at the car, burbling at the curb, then lifts himself up and makes his way to the driver's window. Sara makes a face, bugging her eyes a little-mad at him, but- not without humor. Then she rolls down the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so glad to see you, Sara.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe you. Did that nice doctor let you out? Or-is this you improvising again, Grady?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm through improvising. SARA Terry told me about Wonder Boys. Is  it true? Did you lose it all?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I lost it ail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Grady. You're such a putz.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you're old. Sara strokes his scalp, takes a gray hair between her fingers. Yanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ouch. How many?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dozens. It's very sad. Sara smiles at Grady, but the mischief leaves her eyes when she looks into his, and-she glances away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I went and looked at-some babies just now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess you have to go on faith.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some times...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: studies her as she traces her finger around the HOSPITAL BRACELET still encircling his wrist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you tell Walter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told Walter. GRADY Does he still love you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It didn't come up. GRADY studies Sara's freckled cheeks, her anxious profile, then turns her chin gently toward him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well I do. I've always loved you, Sara. I didn't know it at the time, but I'd always been waiting for you. My whole life. Because you're who I need. Because nothing makes sense without you. Because the best moment of every day is the moment I first see your face. And because when you leave a room, there's no reason to be in it any more. It's just a room again. Sara cocks her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you just make that up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the hospital. I "was kind of excited about it at-the time, but then I was on pretty heavy painkillers. She frowns good-naturedly. GRADY (cont'd) Even so...it's still true. Every word. Sara just nods, looks away, her face unreadable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sara, I promise, even though commonsense might tell you... Sara turns, puts a finger on GRADY's lips...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't write a page when a paragraph will do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: nods, takes her hand. Looks at it as he speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't deserve me, you know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know, but sometimes... Sara turns, looks at Grady. Her eyes are glistening. SARA (cont'd) You just go on faith.
